column4: Oh, so wherever it's being installed should be mounted to "/"
right?
its generally a good idea to have mount /, /usr, /home and /swap on separate partitions
but since you are just starting out, just mount / on /dev/sda4
do you have a separate partition identified for swap?
I was planning on working on the swap after figuring out what the main partition mounts to
I'm not making seperate partitions for each /home, etc, because I'm trying to dual boot (and yes, because I'm just starting out with this.)
ok -- how much is ur RAM?
4GB
Rule of thumb, swap = ram x 2
alright - so your swap shouuld be atelast 4 GB in size
not twice that of ram, the same?
no - ram x 2 would be overkill - it will hardly be used
Ok.
just use the same size as that of RAM if you are  planning to use hibernate
Thanks, Noobuntu
you are welcome
Quick question, you think 68GB is enough for an ubuntu install?
that would depend on how you plan to use it
Bah humbug.. I can never remember if I ran out of space on my last escapade with linux.
if you are asking only about the operating system space requirements then 68GB is of course more than enough
I'm just worried because of all the constant updates?
